qas.question: What does the word prime generally suggest?

answers.text: indecomposability
minimality
minimality or indecomposability
minimality or indecomposability

qas.question: For a field F containing 0 and 1, what would be the prime field?

answers.text: the smallest subfield
the smallest subfield
Q or the finite field with p elements
the smallest subfield

qas.question: What does it mean for a knot to be considered indecomposable?

answers.text: it cannot be written as the knot sum of two nontrivial knots
cannot be written as the knot sum of two nontrivial knots
cannot be written as the knot sum of two nontrivial knots
it cannot be written as the knot sum of two nontrivial knots

qas.question: How can any knot be distinctively indicated?

answers.text: as a connected sum of prime knots
as a connected sum of prime knots
as a connected sum of prime knots
as a connected sum of prime knots

qas.question: What is an additional meaning intended when the word prime is used?

answers.text: any object can be, essentially uniquely, decomposed into its prime components
any object can be, essentially uniquely, decomposed into its prime components
any object can be, essentially uniquely, decomposed into its prime components
any object can be, essentially uniquely, decomposed into its prime components

qas.question: What does the word component generally suggest?
For a field F containing 0 and 1, what would be the prime knot field?

plausible_answers.text: it cannot be written as the knot sum of two nontrivial knots

qas.question: What does it mean for a knot to be considered a p element?

plausible_answers.text: as a connected sum of prime knots

qas.question: How can any knot be a field of F?

plausible_answers.text: any object can be, essentially uniquely, decomposed into its prime components

qas.question: What is an additional meaning intended when the word component is used?

context: The concept of prime number is so important that it has been generalized in different ways in various branches of mathematics. Generally, "prime" indicates <a0_1><a0_2><a0_3>minimality<a0_1/> or <a0_0><b5_0>indecomposability<b5_0/><a0_3/><a0_2/><a0_0/>, in an appropriate sense. For example, the prime field is <a1_0><a1_1><a1_3><b6_0>the smallest subfield<b6_0/><a1_3/><a1_1/><a1_0/> of a field F containing both 0 and 1. It is either <a1_2>Q or the finite field with p elements<a1_2/>, whence the name. Often a second, additional meaning is intended by using the word prime, namely that <a4_0><a4_1><a4_2><a4_3><b9_0>any object can be, essentially uniquely, decomposed into its prime components<b9_0/><a4_3/><a4_2/><a4_1/><a4_0/>. For example, in knot theory, a prime knot is a knot that is indecomposable in the sense that <a2_0><a2_3><b7_0>it <a2_1><a2_2>cannot be written as the knot sum of two nontrivial knots<b7_0/><a2_3/><a2_2/><a2_1/><a2_0/>. Any knot can be uniquely expressed <a3_0><a3_1><a3_2><a3_3><b8_0>as a connected sum of prime knots<b8_0/><a3_3/><a3_2/><a3_1/><a3_0/>. Prime models and prime 3-manifolds are other examples of this type.
